Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2012 07:03AM momof3boys wrote: I guess I'm confused about Rads... I had BMX with TE reconstruction. My surgeon said "no radiation, there's nothing to radiate! I got great margins and there's no nodal involvement!" he was adamant. My MO, when I asked her said, "I don't think so, but, I'm not a radiological oncologist, and you have the right to an opinion from one.... So, she referred me (twice as it turns out, couldn't stand the 1st guy). Long story short, even with great margins (they both agreed to that), and no nodal involvement. They explained that my Low Oncotype score (16) is for Distant recurrence, not local recurrence, and since I'm "so young" (43, hahaha, don't feel so young) and tumor was larger than 2 inches, the protocol is to at least do rads to the incisional scar, bring down my 10 year local recurrence rate of 15% to under 5%.... My MO said that she totally agrees after hearing it explained that way and is glad she referred me to the head of this well respected group. Interestingly, one of her colleagues, a male MO, went thru BC a couple of years ago and also agreed to the incisional scar radiation. My cancer was on the right side, so I'm less worried about heart issues. I do have a lot of time to decide... Wouldn't start until a month after Chemo....

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2012 01:06PM momof3boys wrote: Hi Dave I'm not sure of your wife's type of cancer, size of tumor, stage, grade, surgery, age, etc. My Oncotype score came in at 16. My MO was 50/50 on the chemo because it meant a 10% chance of recurrence, which is 'great'.... But, we finally decided to go ahead with 4 rounds of TC because of my "young age" (43), the fact that the tumor was larger than 2 cm, and the fact that even with negatives nodes, there's a possibility that there are undetectable cancer cells out there... The Oncotype score is for 'distant recurrence' and it just one "tool" that the MO should consider when it comes to chemo. I have 3 young boys, and psychologically, for me, I needed to know I was doing everything I could to raise my 90% chance of no recurrence, ever for an estimated (from MO) 1-4% benefit. It is a personal decision, I have seen many women on these boards with higher scores than mine not do chemo.

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2012 01:50PM momof3boys wrote: Hi Bonnie- I hope this helps...my Oncotype score was 16. My MO was on the fence with recommending chemo for me because I didn't fit into any "box". My tumor was on on the larger side (typical for ILC, it forms more of a "line" than a "lump), but I had no nodal involvement and no vascular invasion. Healed from BMX very well and quickly. We decided to go ahead with 4 tx of TC, because of my "young age" (43) and because my MO said the Oncotype score is just one of the tools that should be considered. It was a tough decision, but I'm glad I made it. It definitely helped that my MO is female, young (about 37-38 ish) and is considered brilliant. She went into BC oncology because her Mom had breast cancer 16 years ago. I also have 3 young children (7,9,16) and I'm determined to do everything aggressively to be here to see them grow up. If I was 65-75 with my "scorecard' I probably would not hesitate, and would turn down the chemo with an Oncotype score of 16 with no nodal involvement and no vascular invasion.

Didn't want to wait "for the other shoe to drop" with mammograms, us, MRI on "good" breast. I'm a nervous type when it comes to waiting on medical results. I know myself very well, and didn't want to put myself through that. 4. My type of cancer has a 20-30% chance of at some point appearing in the opposite breast. 5. After consulting with a PS and going over everything, he said he'd do whatever I wanted, but wanted to disclose that matching a brand new breast to a 43 year old breast is cosmetically very difficult and wanted to make sure I was aware of that. I'm at peace with my decision, wanted to go through mastectomy ONCE!

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2012 12:40AM momof3boys wrote: Renae the T is for Taxotere. You can browse thru some of the December and January chemo threads and get a sense of SE (side effects). We're all different and it's hard to compare because you don't actually know anyone's medical history other than is what is in their BC stat line under their signature, so it's difficult. Some of us come to BC with other issues like diabetes, previous cancers, advanced age, etc. As for me, I don't have any other health issues, I eat well, exercise, normal weight, blood pressure, etc... BC was a complete shock. But, I'm tolerating TC pretty well. I haven't had any nausea, so haven't had to take the added meds they give you for that SE. I have had fatigue which hits on day 3-4 after treatment, but, I've still been able to function and take care of my kids (7,9,16). My biggest SE has been bone pain from the Neulasta shot, but found a tip on here to take Claritin and that actually works... I've lost my hair, but have had to nail or mouth sore issues. I own my own company, so I've been very fortunate in that regard. I've become like Howie Mandel with a fear of germs, so I've been lucky to just come and go at the office as I see fit. I don't want to pick anything up that would land me in the hospital or delay treatment. I feel about 80% of myself for the week before the next treatment, and make it a point to get in 30 minutes of exercise, usually on the treadmill everyday, which is less than what I was doing before my BMX surgery (at least an hour a day)

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2012 11:13PM momof3boys wrote: 7of9- where is the lump in your neck located? I underwent BMX with TE reconstruction, chemo, and radiation this year. About 3 weeks into radiation a large lump popped up on my neck (left side, under my ear about an inch). Well, my Drs absolutely freaked. Because it was on the opposite side from my BC and I had no positive nodes, no LVI, they were pretty confident that it didn't have anything to do with BC. However, lymphoma was a concern. I underwent two ultrasounds, and 3 CT scans in the past few months to monitor it. Everything looked good, glad I got those scans because I probably wouldn't otherwise being stage II. All radiologist reports indicated that it was a left cleft brachial cyst, which is a congenital birth defect. When were forming in utero, we have "gills" on both sides of our neck that should seal and close up. Mine did not. After keeping an eye on it for several months (sometimes they go down on their own) my RO and MO decided to send me to an ENT surgeon. I'm thankful they did. He being more of an expert could see that it was wrapped around my jugular and needed to be removed ASAP. I had that surgery on Friday. The mass on imaging was about 3 cm. When he removed it, it was larger than a golf ball, and fluid filled. It was benign. Very scary. Maybe you could ask for a referral to an ENT surgeon? Btw, the consensus from all Drs was that the stress of surgery, chemo and radiation caused it to react at this time.

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2012 04:59AM momof3boys wrote: Hi Renae! Regarding your SIL; it looks like she had ILC which is very hard to detect with a mammogram, US, or even MRI. It tends to form a "line" of cancer cells, rather than a "lump" and it very difficult to detect. It was the same for me. My MO said that my ILC tumor was probably present thru my last 2-3 mammograms. It was only detected because a more astute radiologist noticed a "pulling" of breast tissue on my last mammogram that he thought looked suspicious. It was never felt by me, my Gyn, the BS the PS or the MO. All examined me before surgery. Scary! With ILC there is a much higher chance, about 30%, that at some time it will appear in your opposite breast. So, because of that and a few other reasons, I decided on BMX. Coincidentally, while I was in surgery, MY SIL's surgeon called her with the results of her biopsy!!! She had a walnut size area of DCIS with a very small amount of IDC in the center. She chose a lumpectomy and started radiation last week. Some in our family are questioning her lumpectomy too. But....most people don't realize that there are different types of BC and they have different characteristics. How's the weather where you are??? If it's nice, go outside for a walk! I'd much rather that than my treadmill. But, use the treadmill for yucky days like snow, cold, or rain. Joyce

Posts.Content: May 13, 2012 10:08PM momof3boys wrote: I finished TC x4 on March 2nd. I'm a lot younger then your Mom (43), but, your Mom isn't old, either. You say she's petite? Sounds like she's in otherwise good health? The chemo wasn't a walk in the park, but, it wasn't horrible either. My Oncotype was 16, and I'd definitely do it again. With your Mom's stats, she could live another 30+ years! I'd definitely do it. My MO said one of the biggest misconceptions women have about chemo is that they're going to lose a lot of weight. Most don't. They actually don't feel as bad as they anticipate, and overeat a but, and actually gain. I was at my ideal weight at the start of chemo, and had to be careful about this. So, don't let your mom being petite worry you too much. Will you or someone else be able to help her with things like laundry, groceries, dinner etc, because she will feel fatigue.

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2012 05:36PM momof3boys wrote: LeesaAnn and all- I can't remember if I told you about my aunt. She was a beautiful woman. She passed away last August, after being breast cancer free for 18 years. She had a UMX, chemo, radiation and was in the group of the first BC patients to get tamoxifen. She did very well for many years (diagnosed mid 40's), and was monitored closely at first, then annually. I don't know the exact details of what went down, but, according to my Mom, her sister: After she and my uncle retired and moved from CT to DE, she got a new dr who told her after ten years, BC free, the standard was to just do a mammogram annually on her remaining breast. She was in good health other than borderline diabetes. Well, once the recurrence was discovered (fatigue, pain in liver) she went to Johns Hopkins and was told that she should have had more followup than just a mammogram annually.... What that was, I don't know, but by the time the recurrence was discovered, it was in her liver, bones, and brain. I don't know what the answer is, but, I think I want to be monitored closely.

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2012 09:04AM momof3boys wrote: Well, I'm back! Everything went well. Got there at 11:30 for bloodwork then met with MO to go over bloodwork (later nurse gave me a copy of bloodwork, they check at least 50-75 different things) I guess the big ones they check are white cell blood count, liver enzymes and calcium (could be indicator of bone met)... Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2012 01:40PM momof3boys wrote: Help! A little freaked out... Yesterday when I went for my infusion, I had my bloodwork done and went to meet (as usual) with my MO before my treatment. She examined me and checked my bloodwork on her computer. She said everything she had (checks like 50-70 things!) was good and she was just missing a couple of results, but to go over and get started. I did and they did start the infusion, I asked the nurse if they got the final results and she said yes, they'd get me a copy. Never asked for a copy before. Read it this morning and every test was in the normal range except for the alkaline phosphatase. It was 155. Normal ranges are 34-104. Before I started chemo it was 63, after first tx it was 145, now 155. This is all on the paper in columns. I called my MO and she said she wasn't concerned...feels that is was normal before chemo and is most likely caused by the chemo or the Neulasta. But, she offered to send me for a bone scan while trying to assure me that she's just doing this to ease my mind. Anyone else look at all their bloodwork? Out of normal ranges?

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2012 05:30AM momof3boys wrote: Thanks Wave!! XO Just got back from final tx! Yay! I was really nervous because it took 30 minutes to get the liver and kidney function bloodwork back. When she gave me a copy, I searched first for that alkaline phosphotase results. Dropped in half, back down in normal range. MO said she's not worried at all during chemo what these tests say, they're normally all over the board. But, she knows I obsess over everything.... She's calling over to RO to let him know that today was my last chemo, and they'll set me up for rads in about 4 weeks. She said I'd have to meet with the RO again beforehand. And also that she agrees with doing the incisional scar only. First guy wanted to do that, plus two areas of lymph nodes.... Geesh my lymph nodes were all clear. She did give me a very thorough exam. And told me after rads, I would be starting Tamoxifin. She said that there are different brands of Tamoxifin, so if I have SE, we'll just switch till we get it right. I swear she checked/ felt every lymph node in my body! I'll be getting blood work every three months for two year, then every 6 months for 3 years. She said scans (in lower stages) are not ordered unless it's necessary, or new symptoms. But, she said a lot of women worry and let it take over their heads, and if I'm worried about something, just call her and she'll order a scan. She reminded me that I was "very low risk" for recurrence and have treated very aggressively, so she hopes I can go thru rads and then relax!

This is the same kid that said to the waitress at Olive Garden on Sunday, when she asked me if I wanted a sample of wine..."she can't, she's on chemo" !!! Ugh....

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2012 03:58PM momof3boys wrote: I think the psychological affects of this BC disease is traumatizing. I know for me, every ache and pain is analyzed in my head, over and over. It's paralyzingly painful. Remember when I went thru that period where my alkaline phosphatase level was raised and my MO told me 3 times it was because of chemo? Finally, she said "I'm confident it's raised because of the chemo, but, I'm going to order a bone scan because I can see that you're not able to move forward without it". I was terrified of that bone scan, but she was right... At my last appt with her, she told me that her Mom (BC survivor 16 years) was in that day for bloodwork and called my MO after meeting with her own oncologist. She said that her Mom asked her "tell me the truth, is my bloodwork really ok?" "Look up to see if he (mo) wrote any notes that he didn't tell me about" She really gets the anxiety that we feel, yet is calming at the same time. I've thought of talking to someone about this anxiety, but really, unless they have BC, they can't really know what I'm going through... I wish there was some kind of scanner in my shower that would beep if I had anything to worry about, then I'd get it out of my head for the day!

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2012 01:13AM momof3boys wrote: @voraciousreader: I'm not sure what my MO based that on. She just stated that as a matter of practice for her group, they use "11" as a cutoff point for young, otherwise healthy BC patients. I took that to mean anything under 11, would not recommend chemo. Above 11, would look at the Oncotype score plus other mitigating factors in recommending whether to do or not do chemo. My score was 16. She didn't push me either way until I made the decision to do chemo, then she did tell me that if it were her, she would do the same thing. I had a low score, no nodal involvement, no LVI, but a larger tumor. I'm 43, and premenupausal, very good shape, fit, active, etc...young children.

Saw the RO today. I will see him each Tuesday. He said the best thing for fatigue is just to forge my way thru it?!? Also found out that I'll be having bloodwork done each week. He said radiation causes anemia, so they keep a close watch on your blood levels. My 7 yr old explanation for my headache over the weekend? "Mommy, maybe it's your hair trying to push out" lol I was picturing the playdoh barber shop where the hair grows when you push down on the playdoh. Oh, if it were only that simple! Anyone else see the news about breast cancer being over diagnosed? Made me so mad! From so many posts that I read on BCO I've come to the conclusion that doctors need continuing education with breast cancer... There are so many posts from women on this board that make me say "What was that Dr thinking?" it's crazy. I'm very thankful for the treatment that I've received since I've been diagnosed, but in the back of my head, I worry about screening and health care in this country for women. Right when I was diagnosed, the news was about recommending women not be screened until they're 50...I'm 43. And every three years is good enough with pap smears... My PS made a statement to me when I was trying to decide about chemo (Oncotype 16). He said,"if you lived in the UK or Canada and had negative nodes, you'd be done right now. You wouldn't even be given a choice. But, the US had a 29% higher survival rate for BC." I do worry about women coming behind us and the Oncotype test. I can definitely seeing insurance companies refusing to cover women like me with low risk scores. My Drs have been pretty vocal that coverage will change, not fir the better, if health care is mandated. I'm sure youve all read posts from women in UK and elsewhere that wait WEEKS for mammograms, biopsies, test results, it's scary. Just my thoughts...

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2012 11:06PM momof3boys wrote: Hi Renae..I'm sure your MO is going to take everything into consideration before making a recommendation for or against chemo, then it will be up to you to decide what you feel comfortable with. For me, before my BMX, I met with my MO and she said based upon the size of the tumor, and my age 43 (considered young for BC) she was 90% sure I'd be doing chemo. Then my Oncotype score came in at 16, so she was "on the fence". She told me that "you wouldn't be wrong to turn down chemo, but I can't tell you that you'd be right either" because I didn't fit into any "box" that made it clear cut. I didn't have any node involvement, and no vascular invasion. It was a tough decision, but we did decide to go ahead with chemo. I'm doing 4 TC (3rd is this Thursday). She did tell me that her group (10 MO's) uses 11 as the cutoff for young, otherwise healthy patients. And also, with that low of a score she would not prescribe any chemo that may cause heart damage later on. I've heard other women refer to TC as "chemo lite" and while I would never agree to that, it hasn't been too terribly bad and I mentally feel more confident knowing that I did what I could to prevent a recurrance. I know some will not agree with me, but, I just think that the Oncotype score is just one tool to be used to determine recurrance and if one should or shouldn't do chemo. You need to be confident and believe in your own decisions. Good luck tomorrow!

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2012 10:13PM momof3boys wrote: I did a BMX with reconstruction, chemo and radiation. Got 4 opinions on the radiation. My RO explained that the risk of local recurrence is very different than distant recurrence (I had a low Oncotype score) and the most likely place for recurrence is just underneath the incisional scar. So, since my ILC tumor was just over 4cm, they recommended it, and I did it. I did research he risks and long term risks and SE. But, something one of the RO's said to m when I brought up potential future cancers "But, you have a known cancer now, let's make sure we eradicate that" That made sense to me.... I know it's a tough decision, good luck.

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2011 09:03AM momof3boys wrote: I'm feeling about 90% after double mastectomy and reconstruction. I wake up achey in the morning, and feel better the more I move around. Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2012 03:29PM momof3boys wrote: Hi Ronnie, the odds are in your favor that this is benign, so try to relax until you have a definitive answer- I know- impossible... That being said, if I knew then what I know now....I had regular mammograms since the age of 32 (maternal aunt with BC). Heard the comment plenty of times "oh, you have dense breasts". After being diagnosed with BC last fall at age 43, my oncologist told me that young women (they consider 43 to be young!) with dense breasts should be getting MRI's, not mammograms. I did have a baseline MRI at 40. I didn't know that my insurance co refused to pay for yearly MRI's and had mammograms after that. My MO said my tumor had to have been there thru the last 2-3 mammograms... So, demand that your dr write you a script for a breast MRI. And, pass the word to any woman that mentions that she has dense breasts.

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2011 08:50AM momof3boys wrote: Actually, in the months before being diagnosed, I lost 30 lbs on the Dukan Diet, and it was a struggle. I definitely do not want to regain any weight, as I feel so much bettet and have so much more energy at 153 as opposed to the heavier weight. So, I'm concerned with that and that the oncologist stressed that women that don't gain weight, have better outcomes.... She did say (and she's very naturally thin) that chemo does have a tendency to make you gain a little bit of weight, but alot of women, over eat in the weeks between treatment, anticipating that they are going to be sick and lose weight in the week after treatment, and they (her patients) don't end up being as physically sick as they feared. So, she said to be aware of that. I've prepared my kids about my hair loss..... (three boys: 7,9 &16). I've reassured them that the cancer is not going to cause me to lose my hair, but the medicine that will help make the cancer not come back will make me lose my hair, that was reassuring to them). I also made them all laugh when I suggested that they shave their heads in support of me....hahaha! They all said, that's ok, but, we're not doing that! (They all have buzz cuts anyway)

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2011 09:27PM momof3boys wrote: Hi Rachel PT wasn't suggested to me after the double mastectomy and immediate reconstruction. Interestingly, my PS put me through a bunch of range of motion and strength tests before the surgery, and I'm physically fit. I'm concerned about weight gain because: psychologically I know it will be hard for me to take one more thing! I just recently lost 30 lbs and am very happy right now with my weight. My oncologist said some weight gain is normal, but to watch. She said a lot of women overeat between chemo in anticipation of being sick...and a good number aren't that sick after all. Also, she said that in her experience, women with a healthy weight do better during and after treatment. There's actually a gym attached to the facility that I will receive my chemo and my insurance covers the membership (it's owned by the Drs in her practice). She also recommended swimming and again said she'd write a prescription for it so I could use an indoor pool near my home that is located in a rehab hospital.

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2012 09:02AM momof3boys wrote: That's a tough one! How many men has the Ontotype test been done on? Does it matter whether you're male or female? If you took that test out of the equation, according to my MO, you'd do chemo because the tumor was larger than 2cm. My score was 16, no nodal involvement, no vascular invasion, larger tumor, but low Oncotype score. After going back and forth, I decided to go ahead with chemo. I'm 43, no other health issues, tolerating TC (just did 3 of 4 on Thursday) well. If I were over 65 with a 16 Oncotype score, I think I would have have done the chemo. But at 43 with three boys to raise and a tumor over 2 cm, my gut was telling me to do it. Your score of 5 is so low.... My MO's group uses 11 as a cutoff for chemo, but I'm thinking it's mostly women. Although, one of the MO's himself (Dr Heim, Scranton PA) had breast cancer. Maybe look him up? I think the size of your tumor is the difficult part in the decision?
